questions.text: What is the most common site of fistulization in GIT?
questions.solution:
The esophagus is the most common site of fistulization in the gastrointestinal tract (GIT).

A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. The fistula is usually present near the tracheal bifurcation, with or without esophageal atresia. A blind proximal pouch with a distal tracheo­oesophageal fistula is the most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula (Type C).

10% of the patients have associated VACTERL anomalies (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb).

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: What is the most frequent site of ectopic gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
The most frequent site of the ectopic gastric mucosa is the upper third of the esophagus, where it is referred to as an inlet patch.

It is congenital and mostly asymptomatic. Occasionally, it can release acid, which can result in dysphagia, esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or, rarely, adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man came with complaints of difficulty in swallowing and a persistent feeling of something stuck in his throat. He also reports bad breath and regurgitation of food particles. Barium swallow revealed the following. This condition occurs due to a defect in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image are diagnostic of Zenker’s diverticulum. It occurs due to a defect in the Killian's triangle (Killian's dehiscence).

Killian's triangle is an anatomical triangular area bordered superiorly by the firm oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and inferiorly by the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. It is located immediately above the upper esophageal sphincter.

Although the Killian-Jamieson diverticulum is an anterolateral defect, it is rarely symptomatic.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

questions.text: All of the following may be seen in patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Paterson–Brown–Kelly or Plummer–Vinson syndrome is associated with non-progressive dysphagia, especially with incompletely chewed food.

This syndrome is common in women aged >40 years. The other components of this syndrome are:

  • Post-cricoid webs in the upper esophagus
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Glossitis
  • Cheilosis

Esophageal webs are idiopathic, semi-circumferential lesions composed of fibrovascular connective tissue and overlying epithelium. They are usually limited to the proximal esophagus and may cause obstruction. They are associated with:

  • Plummer–Vinson syndrome
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Chronic graft-versus-host disease
  • Blistering skin diseases

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with complaints of difficulty in swallowing solid foods. An upper GI endoscopy revealed the following finding just above the gastroesophageal junction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an esophageal ring. Rings located above the gastroesophageal junction are classified as type A esophageal rings.

Esophageal rings are circumferential and thick. They include mucosa, submucosa, and occasionally, hypertrophic muscularis propria. There are 3 types:

Type A rings Type B or Schatzki rings Type C rings

Caused by normal physiologic smooth muscle contractions

Most common type

Associated with hiatus hernia

Rare findings

Indentations on radiographic studies due to diaphragmatic crural pressure

Seen above the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) in the distal esophagus

Covered by squamous mucosa

Located at the squamocolumnar junction

Covered by gastric cardia-type mucosa

 Found in the most distal portion of the esophagus

Steakhouse syndrome refers to intermittent food impaction causing complete obstruction due to the presence of Schatzki rings.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is being evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. She traveled to Brazil on a business trip 5 months ago. Barium swallow reveals the following finding. Which of the following could have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia. With respect to this patient's travel history, Chagas' disease due to infection with Trypanosoma cruzi must be suspected.

The infection destroys the myenteric plexus which results in failure of peristalsis and esophageal dilatation. Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas' disease.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?

choices.text: Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the  lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and VIP(vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus.

Normally, NO and VIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in the distal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP. This causes increased LES tone.

The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:

  1. Incomplete relaxation of LES
  2. Increased tone of LES
  3. Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about eosinophilic esophagitis?

choices.text: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
Treatment of choice is systemic steroids
May be associated with food products like cow’s milk and soy products

questions.solution:
Treatment of choice are proton pump inhibitors, which when started as primary therapy is effective in 30 - 50 % of affected individuals. 
Additionally, elimination of allergenic proteins from diet as it is is associated with atopy and exposure to food allergens like cow’s milk and soy products.
Swallowed topical steroids are used as well.

Immunocompromised patients are treated with acyclovir, famciclovir or valacyclovir.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to you with progressive heartburn and difficulty in swallowing. She also describes episodes of painful blanching and bluish discoloration of her fingers and toes on exposure to cold. The following findings are noted on examination. Antibodies to which of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are the characteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins (anti-centromere antibodies).

CREST syndrome is characterized by the following:

  • Calcinosis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

In the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads to hypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops a rubber-hose–like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter gives rise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with blood in his vomitus. He gives a history of binge drinking followed by multiple episodes of vomiting the prior night. He is hemodynamically stable.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It is due to longitudinal mucosal tears
The gastroesophageal musculature fails to relax
The tears cross the gastroesophageal junction

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory–Weiss tear. They require only conservative management and healing tends to be rapid and complete.

They are longitudinal mucosal tears that may cross the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ). Forceful retching or vomiting along with failure of reflex relaxation of the gastroesophageal musculature results in tears involving the mucosa and submucosa. It usually occurs secondary to conditions like acute alcohol intoxication or hyperemesis gravidarum.

Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural rupture of the distal esophagus. This results in acute mediastinitis with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock. Such patients generally require urgent surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of esophagitis?
questions.solution:
The most frequent cause of esophagitis is reflux of gastric acid into the lower esophagus.

The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. Reflux esophagitis leads to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This can cause Barrett's esophagus and eventually can cause adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which organism can cause esophageal infections in healthy individuals?
questions.solution:
Esophagitis in healthy individuals can be caused by the Herpes simplex virus. However, it is relatively uncommon.

In immunosuppressed individuals, infections can be caused by:

  • Herpes simplex virus 
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Candida

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by:
questions.solution:
Infection with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically results in punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted:

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies

Note: CMV esophagitis causes shallow ulcerations. The biopsy is taken from the base of the ulcer and shows characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions bodies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with haematemesis is found to have the following finding on upper GI endoscopy. He has traveled to Zambia several times over the past 3 years. What could be the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing bleeding esophageal varices are suggestive of hepatic schistosomiasis. It is the second most common cause of varices worldwide.

Liver cirrhosis, mostly in association with alcoholic liver disease, is the most common cause of varices.

questions.text: All are true about Barrett oesophagus except:

choices.text: Seen in 10% of  individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.solution:
Barrett's esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of GERD and it is estimated to occur in as many as 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for esophageal cancer?
questions.solution:
Mediastinal fibrosis does not predispose to esophageal carcinoma. Risk factors for esophageal carcinoma include the following: 

  • Alcohol and tobacco use
  • Poverty
  • Caustic alkali burns
  • Diverticula
  • Achalasia
  • Tylosis
  • Plummer–Vinson syndrome
  • Frequent consumption of very hot beverages
  • Radiation exposure to the mediastinum
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection - squamous cell carcinomas

questions.text: A patient with recurrent gastritis has been diagnosed with Helicobacter pylori infection. Which of the following is true in this patient?

choices.text: Increased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Decreased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus
Decreased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus

questions.solution:
Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Long-standing H. pylori gastritis (chronic inflammation) causes multifocal gastric mucosal atrophy, which in turn leads to reduced parietal cell mass, acid secretion. This leads to reduced incidence of Barrett's esophagus and decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. 

H. pylori infection, however, increases the risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the oesophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding?
questions.solution: The given images showing an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy and apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus on barium swallow are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 4.
